MainHeading.Title: Adjournment Matters. - Printing of Examination Papers.

Speaker.P: It is nice to welcome the Minister to the House. It is a change for the appropriate Minister to take the Ajournment matter on an issue on which he has knowledge and the authority to speak.

MainHeading.P: I am raising the subject of the printing of the junior certificate examination papers overseas because I wish to know the Government policy on this issue. It seems there is no Government policy on the printing of leaving certificate, junior certificate or any examination papers. I am not saying that there should be necessarily a policy to print them willy nilly in Ireland; I want him to tell me why they were not printed in Ireland but that the contract went to an overseas printing firm. I understand — it has not yet been confirmed — that the contract has gone to a printing firm in Hertfordshire. I hope the Minister does not give me the reply, which I have received from other sources, that he is compelled, by European Union rules, to put this out to tender.

I thoroughly approve of competitive forces. Putting the contract out to tender is a laudable objective. However, I draw the Minister's attention — it is one of the rules of the Adjournment that we do not see the Minister's reply before we ask the question but anticipate it — to the EC Directive of 1976 which is specific in saying that supply contracts of less than 200,000 European units of account can be exempted in as much as their impact on competition is limited — at today's ECU levels, that is approximately £160,000. This contract would be exempt because it is far below the £160,000 threshold. It is far below that threshold — it is worth between £80,000-£90,000. EU competition rules only apply when the amount is large enough to be material in EU terms. EU rules regard a contract of this size as immaterial. It is at the discretion of the individual State to award it to one of its national companies. There is discontent among some of our publishing companies that this contract was awarded abroad. The Government is not compelled to do this because of the exemption rules, of which I am sure the Minister is aware.

How much money will be saved by the State in awarding this contract to Stephen Austin's printers in Hertfordshire? How far is this measured against employment? How many jobs does the Minister feel have been lost as a result of this? What will be the future policy on contracts of this sort? The Minister can tell me if I am incorrect, if the EU directive is immaterial and this is not exempt. The EU is specific in saying that the Government is at liberty to award this contract to an Irish company and need not put it out to competitive tender. However, in the interest of open Government and freedom of information, of which this Government is a great champion, we might hear what the tenders were, how much is being saved by awarding this contract abroad and, indeed, what Government policy will be on contracts of this size — not above the 200,000 ECU limit — in future?

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Education (Mr. Currie) Minister of State at the Department of Education (Mr. Currie)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Education (Mr. Currie)
Speaker.P: The majority of examination question papers for my Department's 1995 certificate examinations are being printed in Ireland. The work is done within my Department and by a commercial printing firm. The balance of the work is being undertaken under contract by a firm outside Ireland.

In dealing with public contracts for the printing of examination question papers, my Department is aware of the need to obtain the services of reputable and reliable firms in the context of fair commercial competition with the objective of securing full value for public funds. The tender for the printing of the examination question papers each year is competitive and my Department has received tenders from firms outside Ireland in the past, but this is the first occasion on which such a tender has been accepted.

MainHeading.P: The performance of firms contracted to work on the examination question papers is closely monitored each year and rigorously assessed for future reference. The performance of the firms contracted to work on the 1995 papers will be appraised in this manner prior to a decision on the printing of the papers for future examinations. The opening of EU markets to Irish companies has brought considerable benefits to this country in recent years and it must be remembered that our EU partners also have access to our markets in the reciprocal arrangements that apply.

That is my official reply, but since the Senator has raised other matters, I will endeavour to reply to some of them. I have not quoted the 1976 EC regulation to which the Senator referred and we are not relying on it. This contract was awarded to the company that made the lowest tender. From my knowledge of the Senator, his commitment to free market principles——

Speaker.P: And we know it too.
——and value for money, I would be extremely surprised if he were to suggest that we do anything else but get value for money in this instance.

The Senator asked for some information about the size of the other tenders. I am not sure that he would entirely agree with me giving out all the information he requested. He may think that some information of a commercial nature ought to remain private and confidential; it would again be contrary to his often expressed views if I were to do anything different. The tender was £10,000 lower than the lowest of the other five tenders received and very substantially lower than most of them.

No jobs have been lost. This Government is particularly concerned with the preservation of jobs and the creation of new ones. We would be concerned if we felt there was any threat to jobs in this or any other area. In this instance, we have been insistent in getting value for money and I hope the Senator will approve of that.

I have a supplementary question. I fully understand the Minister's sentiments. From my knowledge of his political career. I am delighted that he is abandoning his commitment to isolated nationalism and is now taking a wider view of the world. He is prepared to put contracts out to competitive tender and not only to award them to Irish firms. In calculating the cost of these contracts and of awarding them to overseas companies — this decision was made by the Minister's predecessor but he must defend it — does the Department take into account the costs of transporting those exam papers backwards and forwards across the Irish Sea, the number of journeys which have to be made and the number of civil servants who have to accompany the papers and who, I gather, are necessary for security reasons in every case? I also gather that these exam papers are transported not in one but in several loads and several journeys have to be made. It is far more expensive to transport them from Hertfordshire than from somewhere in Ireland. I would be grateful if the Minister could say what the comparative costs are.

There is no rule which states one should not enjoy one's politics and the Senator is obviously enjoying himself. I had not considered that there would be any enormous expense in transporting examination papers across the Irish Sea. The Senator referred to isolated nationalism. He was the one who raised this matter and voiced his concern about junior certificate examination papers being printed outside the country. British firms were allowed to submit tenders in 1992, but because of a number of circumstances which applied that year it was decided to award the contract to Irish based firms. Having established the competitiveness of British firms, it was decided that, as in the case of all new firms, they should be invited to tender for the least sensitive examination only, that is the junior certificate. This is not a new issue. In 1993 and 1994 the lowest tenders were submitted by an Irish firm and the contract was awarded accordingly. This year the contract was awarded to a British firm, purely on the grounds that it submitted the lowest tender. If next year an Irish firm submits the lowest tender it will be awarded the contract.

MainHeading.Title: Adjournment Matters. - Rathkeale (Limerick) Circuit Court Sittings.

Speaker.P: I welcome the Minister for Justice on her first occasion in the House.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Kiely Mr. R. Kiely
Speaker.P: I join with you in welcoming the Minister. I congratulate her on her appointment and wish her well, however long her appointment will last after the events of today, which I will leave aside. I sincerely wish her well.
May I share my time with Senator Neville?
Is that agreed? Agreed.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Kiely Mr. R. Kiely
Speaker.P: We are both concerned about the impending decision of the Department of Justice to transfer the entire Rathkeale list of Circuit Court cases to Limerick city. The Rathkeale Circuit Court was set up by the British Government in the 1880s. Rathkeale was one of the main towns in County Limerick at the time. It would be a pity to see an Irish Government deciding to abandon these sittings or transferring them to Limerick. I, accompanied by Senator Neville, was with a deputation from Rathkeale last week on other matters. Rathkeale needs assistance and not persecution. We need to ensure that it keeps what it has.

MainHeading.P: The list of Circuit Court cases in Rathkeale over the past five or six years has been steadily increasing. Despite the enormous efforts of Judge Kevin O' Higgins to deal with the inexorable increases in the list, he is definitely losing the battle. A typical Circuit Court sitting in Rathkeale would consist of dealing with licensing applications, notices of motion, appeals, both civil and criminal, from the District Court and normal Circuit Court civil litigation. The court is expected to deal with all of this in one sitting. Despite the fact that, in an effort to stem the tide it sits from 10.30 a.m. to 6 p.m. and sometimes later, the list is fast becoming unmanageable due to the number of cases coming in for hearing.

I understand that approximately 1,600 to 1,700 civil bills are set down for trial for Limerick city and county each year. Approximately 40 of them reach trial stage. The average delay between the date one sets a case down for hearing and the actual hearing is approximately a year and a half. However, in some cases the delay could be as long as two and a half or three years. This applies to Rathkeale and Limerick city and I am sure Senator Neville would agree with me.

Limerick city has an average of 30 jury trials coming before the Circuit Court per year. One must bear in mind that this is on top of other criminal cases dealt with by the Circuit Court in Limerick city. With regard to family law, my information is that approximately 60 to 70 family law cases are added to the city court list every year. If one looks at the Circuit Court in Limerick city alone, it is clearly evident that it has too much work coming on stream for one Circuit Court judge.

In Rathkeale the civil and criminal list has been increasing inexorably over the past six to seven years and there is an average delay of eight months to three years in dealing with civil cases. Furthermore, one should bear in mind that the Circuit Court sits in Rathkeale for four days each calender year. The arranged sittings for 1995 are as follows: 18 January, 29 March, 21 June and 22 November. Is it any wonder that there is a delay of 18 months and, in some cases, three years in having cases heard in Rathkeale Circuit Court, given the service I have outlined? The people and community council of Rathkeale are aware of the facilities needed. I am sure the council would provide the new community centre, which was the old courthouse, for sitting and I am sure Senator Neville would agree with this. Instead of transferring sitting from the Rathkeale Circuit Court to the Circuit Court in Limerick, there should be an increase in the number of sittings in Rathkeale from four to at least six to deal with these cases. The judge and the members of the legal profession servicing that area are very much in favour of retaining Circuit Court sittings in Rathkeale. The decision of the Department of justice to transfer Circuit Court cases from Rathkeale to Limerick city should be reversed and I appeal to the Minister not to interfere with Rathkeale Circuit Court but leave it as it is, or maybe have more sittings there.

Speaker.P: I welcome the Minister on her first visit to the Seanad and wish her well in her very responsible brief. I thank Senator Kiely for raising this issue, which is important to the town of Rathkeale. The word went out earlier that there was a proposal from the Department. We now know differently. The committee under the chairmanship of Mr. Justice Spain, the President of the Circuit Court, which was established by the Minister's predecessor, Deputy Máire Geoghegan-Quinn, has not yet made its recommendations, but there is no smoke without fire. We feel in Rathkeale that if these proposals are appearing in the press, they are coming from somewhere. We are extremely concerned about the situation.

There are four sittings a year, sometimes more. It is very important to Rathkeale that it holds this number. Over a period of time we feel that many of the services we had in the town have been removed or downgraded. We feel this is the start of downgrading the whole courts system and that the District Court will be next. If the court sittings are transferred to Limerick, they will enter a system in which delays for both civil and criminal cases extend to two and half years. The waiting period in Rathkeale is about 12 months so if you remove those sittings to Limerick you will further clog up a system which already is not operating.

MainHeading.P: A 40-mile round trip is involved for many people in getting to Limerick and they are unlikely to have their cases heard on the day they travel. This means they might have to make the journey two or three times. In Rathkeale, however, there is an arrangement for a one day sitting when all cases are heard.

In her statement of 17 January, the Minister stated, “My Government is committed to ensuring that the courts system is organised in such a way as to give the best possible service to the public”. I welcome that statement because decisions like this are based too often on commerciality — what is cheapest and more efficient from a monetary point of view.

The Minister has said she will look at proposals to give the best possible service to the public, and that is one reason we are asking her to do so. It is in the best interests of the public that the sittings in Rathkeale continue. It is also in the best interests of the legal profession whose members have made submissions to the committee and have written to public representatives. Judge Kevin O'Higgins expressed his concern about this to legal representatives and said he would be disappointed if such proposals were made.

It is in the best interests of the people involved in the courts, including court staff, to have sittings in Rathkeale. The facilities may need to be upgraded and improved but the conditions are not bad and members of the legal profession have said they are satisfied with them.

We have not had a discussion about the situation in Rathkeale for some time. Rathkeale is unique in that we have two communities; a travelling community consisting of 45 per cent of the people and a settled community consisting of 55 per cent. We are dealing with the unique problems in a tolerant way with understanding from both communities. Even though there are extreme difficulties at times, people are dealing with them. They want to build up their town and keep what is there. While people are often not attracted to a town like Rathkeale, it is becoming more attractive. We want more services there and feel that the loss of any service — even the Circuit Court sitting four days a year — is not acceptable. The community council and chamber of commerce feel strongly that the town should not lose its Circuit Court. I hope that the committee looking at this will see the sense of the case that Senator Kiely and I are making, but if they do not I hope the Minister will when she makes a final decision.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: I thank you, a Chathaoirligh, and Senator for welcoming me to the House. Some of you will know that I tried to get in here through the normal, democratic process. As I travelled the 5,000 miles around the country little did I think that my first formal visit to the Seanad would be as Minister for Justice. I am glad to be here to take this important matter on the Adjournment.

I have no proposals to dispense with the sittings of the Circuit Court in Rathkeale, County Limerick. The position is, as Senator Kiely said, that a committee was established by my predecessor, Deputy Geoghegan-Quinn, in March 1994 under the chairmanship of the President of the Circuit Court, to determine the optimum size, number of circuits and number of venues with a view to ensuring the efficient working of the Circuit Court in all areas.

MainHeading.P: Recent articles in the national press have indicated that a report on the reorganisation of the Circuit Court circuits and a review of the number of Circuit Court venues has, in fact, been finalised. I wish to point out that these articles are inaccurate and, in fact, the committee is still in the process of formulating its proposals. The committee has not yet submitted its proposals to me. As soon as they are submitted they will receive my immediate consideration. This Government is committed to ensuring that the courts system is organised in such a way as to give the best possible service to the public. I want to reiterate that, as I said in my statement earlier this year.

I should add that under the terms of section 10 of the Courts of Justice Act, 1947, the fixing of Circuit Court venues is a matter for the President of the Circuit Court in consultation with the Circuit Court judge assigned to the respective circuits.

I want to thank the Senators for raising this issue and for giving me a chance, publicly in the Seanad, to clarify what have been rumours in the newspapers. Since no report has been issued I have made no decisions, although I know that a number of Senators and members of the Lower House have read of these reports in the papers. When the report comes before me, and any recommendations it might contain — it will receive the most serious consideration. I will not make any precipitate decisions.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Kiely Mr. R. Kiely
Speaker.P: I thank the Minister for her reply.

I also thank the Minister. I note that there is a slight conflict between the terms of reference, “efficient working of the Circuit Courts”, and the Minister's approach to it, “the best possible service for the public”.
